document.masterDocTitle: A Rosetta Stone for eastern Pacific Caecidae (Gastropoda: Caenogastropoda)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Rosetta Stone for eastern Pacific Caecidae (Gastropoda: Caenogastropoda)

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Caecum lucidum de Folin, 1867d: 10
, 2 syntypes MNHN-IM-2000-4595, Panama .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 57.
Caecum lucidum
. A . Profile view (SBMNH 452540). B . Ventral view, adult stage (SBMNH 452540). C . Ventral view, subadult stage (SBMNH 452540). D . Profile view, early subadult stage with periostracum (SBMNH 619525). E–F . Syntypes, MNHN-IM-2000-4595. G . Operculum, exterior surface (SBMNH 452559). H . Operculum, interior surface (SBMNH 452540).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 58.
Caecum lucidum
shells at different growth stages. A . Teleoconchs I to III (SBMNH 452558). B . Surface of teleoconch I (SBMNH 452558). C . Surface of teleoconch II (SBMNH 452558). D . Teleoconchs II to IV (SBMNH 452559). E . Teleoconch IV (SBMNH 452561). F . Surface of teleoconch III (SBMNH 452559). G . Teleoconch V (SBMNH 132339). H . Teleoconchs V to VI (SBMNH 452561). I . Surface of teleoconchs IV to V (SBMNH 452561). J . Surface of teleoconch VI (SBMNH 452540). K . Teleoconch VI (SBMNH 452540).

subSubSection.paragraph: Original diagnosis. “Testa tenui, valde arcuata, conica, vitrea, diaphana; costulis angustis irregularibus, valde sinuosis, longitudinaliter ornata et strigis distantibus, transversim cingulata; inter costulas interstitiis latis, longitudinalibus, minutis strigis ornatis.” de Folin (1867d: 10) .

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 59.
Caecum lucidum
. A . Conceptual reconstruction of growth stages. B . Species distribution map.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and Habitat. From San Felipe Point, Baja California , Mexico to Paitilla Point, Panama . Intertidal to
120 m .
Common on coarse sand substrates.

Remarks. The type material of
Caecum lucidum
is comprised of two damaged subadult specimens (MNHN-IM-2000-4595, Figs. 57 E–F), which Kisch (1959a) referred to as “ holotype ” and “ paratype ”. However, de Folin never made a distinction between the two specimens, so they must be treated as syntypes . Although damaged, they provide adequate details for identification.

Lightfoot’s (1993b: 77)
Brochina
species #5 is an example of
Caecum lucidum
, and her assessment of the species was perfect. Early stage subadults are often misidentified as worn subadult
C. subspirale
.
